title: Why Are Some Hitboxes So Fucked Up?
body: Morg Q, Thresh Q, etc. Wish we can have animations that accurately match the hitbox, so we don't have to main every single skillshot champ for a month to know how far we have to dodge. Dunno if that's too much to ask.

I should point out that, though Riot denies that there are problems with hitboxes, they exist in two forms:
- Incorrect hitboxes / ability ranges as compared to visual indicators
- Unstable code that causes hitbox inconsistency, even in low-latency scenarios (in addition to problems caused by normal lag)

For most other game companies, your request is not too much to ask. For Riot... well...

**#**RiotFixYourGame

(side note: wow the forums are buggy, but I am not in the least surprised)

* Player hitboxes are circles centered around what is generally the center of the champion's model. 
* Skill animations do not affect hitbox location.
* Certain animations (i.e.: Vayne's Tumble) will cause the model to tilt on one side, leaving huge portions of the hitbox empty. Other champions (i.e.: Ahri and Vel'koz) have the opposite, parts of their model stick out of the hitbox.
* Tethers will always look weird since they can hit the hitbox at any angle but the spell effect will "snap back" to attach itself to the center of the model.

While some spell hitboxes are indeed on the generous side, most of the issues are related to the disconnect between the champion model and their hitbox.
If you can't tell where your hitbox is, its relative position to your Health Bar does not change.
the fact that you can point out *why* hitboxes are broken doesn't make them any less broken...

A skillshot hitting a champion is nothing more than a point intersecting with a circle.

**Why aren't they making hitboxes match the character model?**
It would be more expensive to calculate and most (if any) gains would be negated by latency. You'd also be able to manipulate your hitbox because certain animations would move/shrink/enlarge it. Just think of how it would impact champions like Zac.

For the sake of consistency, this is the best way to handle hitboxes, even if they look strange in some cases.

tl;dr: The way the game handles skillshot collisions is fine. But numbers (i.e.: clarity, size and speed) on certain abilities could use some tweaking.

I know exactly how hitboxes work.
